text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Grahame)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: WILLIAM SCHAEFER
Present Address: Cavalier
Pioneer Address: Nicola
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1907

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? About 10 or 11.
   How many of these were bachelor's homes? Seven.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Once or twice a week.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Anytime.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Visited without invitations.
   What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Anytime.
   What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Of course.

   How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

   If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?
   Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.
   In a few cases crops were tended or harvested for someone who was ill.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.
   Cards & dances were common.

   Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

   Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? No
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHITECT QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 5
Popular Recreation and Social Life.

RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many houses were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? (Please list names.)

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Once or twice a week?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Anytime.

4. Have you visited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Visit without invitation.

What time of the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Any time.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees," with groups of neighbors come together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Tell what you remember about such gatherings, and if possible, tell what the reasons were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, whilst drives or dances in houses? Describe.

Carol & David went camping.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? No
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built? about 1910

What material was it made of? Lumber

How large was it? Good size

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? Limited liability co.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Village meets

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.) It served a much greater area, including about four school districts.

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? In Barns

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Whist, Euchre, Pinocle

Was there card playing for a prize? No

What dances were popular? Square, Waltz, Polka, Two Step, etc.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. No

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. No one frowned on it, they never heard of it.
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community events, parties, etc., if you have not described these in the School Questionnaire. Give dates.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built? (around 1910)

What material was it made of? (wood)

Was it built by the community through special funds, the school board, or other organizations?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? (Village)

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you have to go to town to have parties?)

Did you have to travel far for other functions? (if you were close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.)

10. How did a school function also? (including about four school districts)

When parties, dances, etc., were held in houses, school houses or halls? (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize? (yes, no)

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. (yes, no)

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. (yes, no)
12. What attempts at formality, or "manners", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? None.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Yes

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

I am 84 years old and never knew of had a chance to attend a Chivaree.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? Local Improvement Club

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

To get roads & other improvements

Saves were $400 or $500 each for local improvement

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community? Yes

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Organized about 1906

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

Practically all.

How many women belonged? How often did it meet? Three or four times a year

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? Yes in the early years

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
13. Was the church known in your community? Yes

Describe what you remember about churchwork, telling how contacts they were.

Have you ever attended a church service?

Describe any other details of visiting or attending a church service.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can recall being established in your community?

Give the date and reason for its being organized.

Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Association in your community?

Tall when it was organized and what stage had it reached by this organization?

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged to it?

How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? No

Then was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

Handwritten: "Russell's Band of Literary Society including only the school band. This included school children and parents."

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

Handwritten: "Dances, concerts, fairs"

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

Handwritten: "In the school or in someone's home"

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? No

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? No Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before
the school was built (for example, clubs, lodges, etc.). If there were none, explain why.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures? Talks on foreign
lands, etc.? Yes

21. What games did boys play in summer (rattlesnake, ball, marbles, fly kites,
etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   *Skating and sherry on nearby Pond*

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  
   *only children*

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
   *Adults had little time for games*

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

**PICNICS AND SPORTS**

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.  
   *July 1906*

26. Who organized it?  
   *Mr. Marnick*

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
   *Entire Community & Surrounding districts*

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
   *Pony races, children's races also races for boys, girls, teenagers*

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
   *People brought own lunch*

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
   *Tea, coffee, sandwiches, salads, etc.*

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
   *About two P.M.*
5. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, baseball, etc.

22. Did anyone play indoor games in winter - card games such as "Happy Face," "Go Fish," "Checkers," or other games?

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PRINCIPLES AND METHODS

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Omaha?

26. Who organized it? (Name)

27. Was it for the entire community or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, civic organization, etc.?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? If so, describe it.

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the arrangements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? (Any other children have the same fun?)

Boy's Girls' Teenagers

30. What arrangements were made for eating? Was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

People brought own dinner

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

Tea, Coffee, Sandwiches - Delicacies, etc.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

Curling Rink built in Nicola about 1926.
35. What changes have you noticed in skating since the first year? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year?
How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local airports, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

Curling Puck briefly in North about 1926
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? About 1922.
Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? Yes.
Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?
Grace Brown.
When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st). May 1st.

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?
What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details. Not at all.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.
There are two libraries in Cavalcade.
Traveling and Mechanics Institute.

48. Was there a school library? Yes. When was it begun? About 1905.
To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?
7.

40. Then did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? If so, did it grow out of or replace the earlier community plans?

Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

What was the sports day usually called (that month, or any special day, such as May 25th or July 4th)?

41. Are there any from your community who have been members of well-known boxing, hall or other teams? Give names and dates.

READING:

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible.) If not all on nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind? (Use extra sheets if necessary.)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

Early Days:

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school?

Give details and dates.

There are two libraries in Covington, but they are travelling and Mediation's local.

48. Was there a school library? Yes.

When was it begun?

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school texts books as additional reading material?
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started? Who started it? 
   Is it still in existence? Yes.
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

   Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

   Russell & Co. Library consisting of about sixty or seventy five books, kept by teacher. Later, Mechanics & Library combined kept by elevator agent. Both still in existence.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?
   Country Gentleman, Saturday Evening Post, Family Herald and Weekly Star and several other farm papers.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? No
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?
   Several dozen of books, no papers.

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain. No
8. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?  
   When was it started?  
   Who started it?  
   Is it still in existence? Yes  
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

50. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

51. Describe later charges in your subscription, such as increase in subscriptions and added others.

52. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? No

53. Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? Brass Euphonium

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Violins

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

in the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

Canadian Born, a few from the states—No old Country folk songs were ever heard.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? yes When was it started? 1910 or Eleven

Who started it? Mr. Schaefer

How long did it continue? Until First War

How many were in it? About 15 to 20

Who was bandmaster? Mr. Schoepf

What instruments were included? Basses Baritone tenors altos Cornets drums slide trombones Reeds

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.

Practice once a week, no uniforms

Fairs, Picnics, Stampedes &c.

This band was organized after the first war was discontinued.

in 1935
56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? (List)

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the West? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

In the community? (Were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.)

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

In the community?

61. Was "folk music" or music of the country you came from popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? If so, when was it started? Who started it? How long did it continue? How many were in it? About who was conductor? What instruments were included? Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.

Meet twice a week. No uniforms!

Fairs, Picnics, Church socials, etc.

The finish was never discontinued. (Later)
The following Members were in military Bands during the First War:

George Willey, Cornetist; Frank Greening, Cornet
James Tompkins, Tuba.

Henry Verne is now Clarinetist in the Toronto Symphony Orchestra.
The following members were in military bands during the first war.

George W. Kelley, Cornetist, French Hornist, Cornetist

Henry Warner is new Clarinetist for the Toronto Symphony Orchestra!
